column1: Before 1 October 2018, will the water ministers of Egypt, Ethiopia, and Sudan meet to resume technical negotiations over the Renaissance Dam?
column6: ['Foreign Policy', 'Security and Conflict']
column11: Water ministers refer to Egypt's Minister of Water Resources and Irrigation, Ethiopia's Minister of Water Irrigation and Electricity, and Sudan's Minister of Electricity and Water Resources. Construction of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD), located in Ethiopia, is more than halfway complete. However, ongoing technical negotiations between Egypt, Ethiopia and Sudan have hit a roadblock as Egypt has concerns over its downstream access to Nile water (Arab News, Stratfor, Global Construction Review). Confused? Check our FAQ or ask us for help.

column6: https://www.egypttoday.com/Article/1/47025/Egypt-Sudan-Ethiopia-resume-tripartite-talks-on-GERD-in-Khartoum

http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-04/05/c_137089033.htm KHARTOUM, April 4 (Xinhua) -- Delegations of Egypt and Ethiopia on Wednesday arrived in the Sudanese capital Khartoum to take part in a tripartite meeting regarding the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD). Sudan's Foreign Minister Ibrahim Ghandour and Sudan's Water Resources and Electricity Minister Mutaz Mussa received the Egyptian and Ethiopian delegations participating in the meeting. The Egyptian delegation includes Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry, Water Resources and Irrigation Minister Mohamed Abdel Atti and Acting Chief of General Intelligence Service Abbas Mustafa Kamel. While the Ethiopian delegation includes Minister of Foreign Affairs Workneh Gebeyehu, Minister of Water, Irrigation and Electricity, Sileshi Bekele, and Deputy Chief of Security and Intelligence.

Supposedly meeting this week. But not 100% will actually happen - talks previously scheduled didn’t happen. https://www.albawaba.com/news/egypt-ethiopia-sudan-set-discuss-controversial-dam-next-month-1102140
The meeting is set for 4-5 APR.
Leaders are discussing and the Ethiopian water dam in nearly complete.

Based on reading, there has been no new news reported in the United States since March 21, 2018. According to AL-Monitor it appears that Ethiopia is prepared to continue construction and filling plans regardless of Egypt's concerns about the effects it will have down river. With on going water shortages cropping up and continued abrasive behavior between Egypt and Ethiopia, I don't see either of them sitting at the table anytime soon to negotiate, just further delays. Much like we have been warned about Climate Change being a global security risk, this is likely to turn out to be another example of that. Without proper negotiations it could result in a conflict.

Due to the perceived successful of recent talks between the leaders of all three countries, I believe that technical negotiations will not only resume but be completely resolved. Due to the fact that all leaders gave themselves a one month deadline in laying out ways to break the deadlock during a recent meeting in January, by the First of October should definitely see some progress and development be resolved on this issue. I want to remain optimistic and say that due to increasingly advanced technology, all three sides on this issue can find a way to compromise and have their biggest concerns answered. The leaders have already agreed to multiple actions in meeting their one month deadline, such as annul state leadership meetings between the three countries and setting up a fund to link the three countries via railway. I overall remain quite optimistic of the developments on this issue.
April meeting

Meeting between Ministers of Foreign Affairs, Ministers of Irrigation, and the Heads of Intelligence for all 3 countries, Egypt, Sudan, and Ethiopia still scheduled for April 4-5 to discuss the Renaissance Dam project.
The water ministers are set to meet in two weeks. Unless something drastic happens, there is little to indicate that this meeting won't occur.
All parties have such a critical interest in this project that it is nearly inevitable they discuss this further and come to an agreement.

Substantially adjusting upward to 60% as Sudan has sent out invitations to both Egypt and Ethiopa to have a meeting on the dam in early April between foreign and water/irrigation ministers. Egypt has expressed a desire to solve the issue without escalation.
Growing tensions in the region.

Egypt, Sudan, and Ethiopia will meet April 4-5 to discuss Renaissance Dam project. Meeting will include the Ministers of Foreign Affairs, Ministers of Irrigation, and the Heads of Intelligence for all 3 countries.
new meeting scheduled https://www.albawaba.com/news/egypt-ethiopia-sudan-set-discuss-controversial-dam-next-month-1102140

Looks like about to happen in April: Sudan said on Tuesday that it would host a meeting between foreign and water ministers and heads of intelligence services form Egypt, Ethiopia and Sudan on April 4-5 regarding the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD). https://www.albawaba.com/news/egypt-ethiopia-sudan-set-discuss-controversial-dam-next-month-1102140

Per widsmith and hazmate - thank you. Sounds like this will be quiet during Egyptian election (no meetings or agreements until after election). After things may get ugly... there has been postulation Darfur and Syria issues exacerbated by failed rainfall etc. Near the end of the article, check out the % of citizens living in Nile basin. https://qz.com/1181318/ethiopia-egypt-sudan-and-eritrea-tensions-over-grand-ethiopian-renaissance-dam-on-nile-river/

The current Egyptian water minister is taking a hard stance on the time frame for the filling of the dam and is at this point unlikely to change his views. He also has the support of the rest of the Egyptian government. Being a national and historical issue for Egypt it is hard to see their stance changing unless the government changes their stance. http://www.arabnews.com/node/1204921/middle-east

Egypt is about to have elections, that will stop everything for a couple of months, then another couple of months for new government to settle in (even it is same people, they still need time), that leaves only 2-3 months before October. Turkey is meddling which is only annoying Egypt more. Egypt has a lot to worry about just now, I think they will not find the time to think hard about this endemic issue.
Postponement due to political uncertainty in Ethiopia. Egypt's stake in successful diplomatic influence on the filing timeline is a national issue.
Ethiopia can seek the needed technical assistance from other sources. Egypt and Sudan have too many immediate issues, esp. around security, to keep up long term displeasure.
This article seems to indicate that the ministers intended to meet recently. They've got 7 months to reschedule before the question closes.
Meeting is likely to happen but unlikely to have results.
Driven by climate change to cooperate.

Almost no possibility because no one is ready to give up major share of water.
time up-date.
Yes, they will meet, but will they resolve the water issue?
They are consumed with them selves, not Humanity...

yes , but inconclusive. Egypt concerned about upstream dam and reduction of Nile flows. I don't see a viable river allocation as on Colorado River at this time so brinkmanship likely to play out in near term.
Looks like former PM Desalegn was a driving factor of the Dam; it remains to be seen whether the next PM will work well with Egypt or not.

I just read about this issue on the BBC. My forecast is largely based on the high need for water issues to be solved, and my bias that the ministers in these countries will agree program needs to be made before the dam is ready to start filling.

The tripartite of ministers has met over 15 times since Sept. 2014. Only twice did at least 6 months pass between those meetings. The Ethiopian government has some incentive to resolve the negotiations with Egypt so it can focus on its current internal unrest.
The obvious reason: water is vital to all these polities.

technical negotiations are critical to the office of ministers of water irrigation and electricity. if they don't meet to negotiate a dam on the largest river in the region they are not doing their jobs and should be fired.
Despite the recent postponement of talks, the next Prime Minister of Ethiopia will likely prioritize GERD discussion.
Overall Political situation in region
Because its water on a desertical place. It is this or people shooting each other.
They will all realize the importance of maintaining water resources in these countries.
One feels compelled to remind @Captbullett and @1derer that just because something urgently needs to be done is not necessarily a basis for predicting that it will be done.

Assuming the state of Emergency lasts the full 6 months, and that little or no progress is made in rescheduling talks during that state of Emergency, that leaves less than 2 months to to schedule and conduct talks to meet the forecast deadline. A extension of the state of emergency is quite possible, adding further delay. More likely, however, is that rescheduling will begin in earnest towards the end of the emergency with a total delay from the original schedule of roughly one year.
A guess
this is a global resource and they must meet to resolve this issue to many live and jobs are ...

They have to, water is a resource to precious for the arid area. War would not solve the problem. However, basic civility and strong Diplomatic haggling should find a compromise between States for the benefit of all...They know better and it's just haggling for a region known to haggle at their local Bazaars... ...
Update: The @RenaissanceDam twitter account posted yesterday that Italian Construction Company Salini Impregilo had reportedly suspended construction activities at the dam.

Heading way up because the meeting that was scheduled for this weekend (see article) has been delayed but I didn't get the impression it wasn't going to happen. Seems more likely that its because of internal Ethiopian political turmoil and not because they are trying to avoid the meeting. Suggests it will happen sometime in the next eight months at least.
International actors with interests in the region (China and others) will force their hand in a resolution. It is against their interests that things escalate in the region.
Everyone needs regional stability

Only 9% "yes" for the following reasons: 1) The dam will adversly impact approximately 100 million Egyptians by desrupting the natural flow of water and will negativiely impact the local agricultural sector. 2) Depite Sisi having a seemingly more lax stance on Nile water rights, he has publicaly condemned the dam and states that "Egypt does not want to go to war with its neighbors." 3) Turkey is gradually getting involved by attempting to establish a third base abroad in Sudan. Egypt claims that Erdogan is a Muslim Brotherhood sympathizer (jeopardizing constructive political dialogue between Sudan and Egypt). 4) Ethiopia and Sudan seem unwavering in their pursuits.
I make this forecast because while Egypt, Ethiopia, and Sudan are in a disagreement, something must be done, and Egypt and Sudan know it. The case is not closed.
Inextricably tied to Ethiopian politics (PM stepped down surpringly and unrelated to this issue)... http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-02/19/c_136984091.htm

The meetings of a tripartite technical committee on the GERD have been fruitless over the past sessions and a new ministerial meeting scheduled for Feb. 24-25 in the Sudanese capital Khartoum has been delayed upon Ethiopia's request due to its current political instability. http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-02/19/c_136984091.htm
Whether they are the technical water ministers or emerging leaders within those nations, the answer is yes.
Does this question include possible newly elected water ministers or governing parties? Or current water ministers only?
Water is no joke.
This issue seems salient enough that the impacts of the negotiated subject will begin to make palpable impacts.
Took current estimate as a base rate, but lowered it a bit since Ethiopian prime minister stepped down a few days ago.
Regime change and resulting instability in Ethiopia will make it less likely that any serious negotiations will take place.
Meetings have been taking place at higher levels. It is probably time to address things at lower, more practical leveels.
Water matters but it will take a crisis to force a solution.
South Africa issues with water shortage will drive leaders to become more concerned about water issues.
They have let multiple le times over the past few years AND none of the countries can afford to a)ignore the problem of )b go to war.
Reducing to 33%. Per commentary from my peers, little incentive to truly negotiate. Water is an important issue in this part of world and tied to many other items - which they can’t agree on.
https://www.wsj.com/articles/ethiopian-leader-to-step-down-in-wake-of-unrest-1518707206 Doesn't really change anything -- meeting can still not go ahead

If Ethiopia's plans continue forward without interruption, eventually the three must meet in order to address water rights or risk open conflict. While I do not think the meeting will happen in February, as construction progresses eventually a meeting must take place, but maybe not before 1 October 2018.

Multiple news sources reported in late January a planned February meeting between the water ministers of Egypt, Ethiopia and Sudan. Rather than the meeting between the three nations to discuss technical issues related to the dam, Egypt and Sudan conducted a bilateral meet between their foreign ministers and high level intelligence officials to speak about international and regional issues of mutual concern. The dam belongs to Ethiopia and they were excluded from the meeting. Egypt and Sudan will have their major water source, the Nile river, compromised when the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam is completed. No opening day for the dam has been announced and it is estimated to be about 60% complete. Egypt and Sudan will likely do whatever they can to make sure the dam never opens or the completion is slowed as much as possible. Treaties and promises are well meaning in that area of the world, but water is in short supply for all three countries. It appears as if Egypt and Sudan have decided to ally and oppose Ethiopia's dam rather than attempt diplomacy. Seems like the correct strategy. I wouldn't trust any of the three countries involved in any way.

The Nile is the lifeblood of Egypt. The Ethiopian dam will impact the water flow downstream. President el-Sisi of Egypt doesn't want to face more domestic unrest if the reduction of water impacts harvests and raises food prices. There is also the possibility that Egypt could launch an airstrike to destroy the dam.
Leaders have called for water ministers to meet but I think there are too many spoilers for a meeting to actually take place between all three.

The ministers have several reasons to promote the discussions. I think as the middle east becomes more unstable, they will want the water issue resolved to cement the process into a signed document one way or another
know the regaion

Although Cairo has softened to consider the Renaissance Dam, with the 2015 study on its effects, it remains adamant that Egypt should control the biggest share of the Nile. Egypt has also accused Sudan of being on the side of Ethiopia and has suggested excluding Khartoum from the negotiations. This is further exacerbated by accusations of Sudan increasing Turkey's and the Muslim Brotherhood's presence in the region, which Egypt is adamant against.
They are not able to do strong negotiations with a clear target. They fritter away it.

Seems like Sudan and Ethiopia are prepared to go ahead with build with or without Egypt. I'm assuming a technical meeting between two out of three countries won't count towards resolving this as 'yes'
They must get a solution for all.
The Nile River is the key.
Need for power. Economic growth will drive them to resolve issues
Too much turmoil in the region for that to happen right now.
It's more important as it meets completion.

For no better reason, researched or otherwise, the Sudan has no obvious reason to participate. If I was Sudan, I would stem (not stop) the flow of the river for both hydroelectric power and irrigation. This would affect flows downstream in Ethiopia. The Ethiopian project will be derailed by such moves upstream by Sudan all with Egypt and its' traditional reliance on the free flow of the river being cut off - really? Will this lack of cooperation lead to potential conflict in the region, Yes!

Baseline probability 33% for each of three countries: - Populations: Egypt 96m, Ethiopia 104m, Sudan 40m - without access to electricity, without improved water: Egypt 0.4%, .07; Ethiopia 76.7, 48.5; Sudan 45% - current allotment under article 5 (signed in 1959 without input from Ethiopia) declaration of principals Egypt 55.5 Ethiopia and Sudan 18.5 each
Egypt has nothing bringing it to the negotiation table. Without incentives, they will veto it by inaction

Egypt needs to coordinate the working of their damn with the the filling of the Renaissance Damn. If the damn is still on track to be completed in October, it seems plausible that Eygpt will not have a choice but to negotiate the technical operations of the damn. The 15% no is if the Damn is delayed or they don't bring Sudan back to the negotiations. I watched this YouTube video https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=G_8X8tbjqjg

Egypt, Ethiopia and Sudan hope to break Nile dam talks deadlock in one month https://www.reuters.com/article/us-africanunion-summit-nile/egypt-ethiopia-and-sudan-hope-to-break-nile-dam-talks-deadlock-in-one-month-idUSKBN1FI1LC
-Egypt and Sudan wary about encroachment of water share - Egypt probably has the might to stop it,or effect its progress

They’ll meet - but that doesn’t mean progress. Like Darfur and Syria, water scarcity/climate could lead to something worse. So they might as well meet, expense some nice food and hang with their homies from other countries while each jockeys for position. They are too narrow minded (and nationalistic) to realize this isn’t zero sum. But chances of them truly working together for common good? About zero percent (rounded up)
Thanks @cdob63 -- that makes alot of sense. It sounds so complicated on the waterfront that they probably would have to involve the tech folks... swimming in honey.
Percentage is higher based on the fact that the question only requires a meeting of the 3 countries rather than an agreement.
No one there ever agrees on anything

The global climate warming crisis and impending lack of potable water in Africa and elsewhere is going to keep the Renaissance Dam at the top of governmental and environmental priority lists. Although the political agendas of each country will continue to conflict with each other, the question of water availability will be on the minds of all concerned.
Egypt and Sudan and Ethiopia should find a commun background to resolve the dispute over the dam

War is extremely unlikely, as Egypt and Ethiopia fought over water two centuries ago. Egypt knows its demand of 90% of the Nile is unreasonable, but will use this position to leverage a higher percentage than its current 65%. Barring highly unlikely war, both sides need to talk to get what they want.

Technical meetings will not resume until political side is negotiated. There are many political issues in the area and one can just assume a lot will be used as leverage to negotiate for the three countries (https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/fr/contents/articles/originals/2016/02/egypt-interview-orabi-sudan-ethiopia-renaissance-dam.html )
This is escalating, so I doubt it ends in "technical" talks any time soon.

@Intriligator: Political dynamics among all actors, including Turkey’s role in Sudan has exacerbated tensions, with Egypt calling for the elimination of Sudan from its role in this project. While the negotiation dynamics center on electricity, water, its negative externalities on Egypt’s water systems, interactions among states, their disputes evitably continue. Concerns regarding the role of the Muslim Brotherhood in the region has intensified; Egypt’s concerns and tensions with Khartoum and Turkey and their relationship with the Brotherhood. Negotiations amid these controversies will inevitably occur at a rate slower than would be expected. However the IFP calls for a: whether resumption of technical talks and not a resolution of conflict parameters. the conflict parameters are relevant to computations, constraints and externalities and its relationship to dispute resolution. The conditional probability of the occurrence of technical talks given the degree of change found during dispute resolution among all parties will determine its outcome; Posterior probabilities, and Prior knowledge along with private information among all state and non-state actors.
Talk is cheap, and there is no obvious reason for talks not to proceed. Doubtless I am missing something.

According to Reuters, the leadership in these countries has directed their water ministers to come up with a report in the next month (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-africanunion-summit-nile/egypt-ethiopia-and-sudan-hope-to-break-nile-dam-talks-deadlock-in-one-month-idUSKBN1FI1LC). So I would assume that they would meet at some point to discuss. However, I'm unsure if they would restart "technical negotiations" (or even what that entails), so I'm hedging until I learn more.
